subtitle: Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. You know, I
know I spend a lot of time talking about
higher consciousness, psychic awareness,
diving into the depths of your psyche,
getting in touch with your deep
inner purpose, actualizing your full
potentials, becoming knowledgeable about
the human potential movement in about a
hundred and fifty years of psychical
research in parapsychology. I hope
you find it inspirational, but I'm also
aware of the fact that life is stressful.
It's easy to kind of fall into a
state where you're stressed out, where
you're frazzled, is a word I often use, and
all you really want
to do is kind of retreat from the world.
In fact, worse than that, maybe you want
to strike back, maybe you want to punch
somebody, maybe even worse, punch
yourself or hurt yourself.
My wife Janelle, ever since I've met
her, has been an expert in a field that
she calls stress management. It used to
be called stress reduction, but she
understands that stress reduction isn't
always the goal. You see, people sometimes
perform at their very best when there is
a certain amount of stress in their life.
The technical term for that is
eustress, meaning good stress, the
kind of stress that keeps you on your
toes, that makes you vigilant and alert
and wide awake and ready for business,
ready for action. So, a certain amount of
stress is good but sometimes we have
habits that we just get into
unconsciously where we get stressed out.
One way to find out if you are
stressed out is just check in with your
body. Is your stomach tight? Are your
shoulders tight? The body can often tell
you. There's another thing that you
can do, which is to set up triggers in
your environment. Triggers, that's the
term my wife loves to use, things that
will remind you simply to relax. Like, you
could put a little sign up on the
refrigerator that just says, "Take a deep
breath." Especially if you're in the habit
of going to the refrigerator or into the
cupboard when you want to relieve your
anxiety through food, which isn’t the
healthiest way to eat. I've
just moved into a home in Albuquerque, a
new home, not brand new but it's new to
us, big house in Albuquerque, six months
ago, actually less than 6 months
ago. One of the things I realized
looking around this big house is that I
have triggers all over the place,
triggers that remind me to be aware of
the potentials of higher consciousness
or deeper consciousness. Sometimes if you
watch the New Thinking Allowed interviews,
you'll notice my lapel pin, the rainbow
yin yang lapel pin. It's the same as the
design on the logo. If you go to the
New Thinking Allowed Foundation website,
you'll see that we sell those lapel pins
at a very reasonable price. It's a
trigger. It's a reminder, the rainbow
yin yang is a symbol of non-duality, of
the wholeness of consciousness, how
separation is kind of an illusion
because every yin contains within it the
seed of a yang
and vice versa. Between the two yin
and yang elements, well, you have the
complete spectrum, the complete color
spectrum. But, that's just one example of
a trigger. Another example,
undoubtedly many people have noticed in
the interviews, I have a sculpture here
in the studio and people often ask about
it. The name of the sculpture is "Family."
It’s from Zimbabwe, made by the Shona
people. It's sculpted in soapstone. But, it
stands there in the middle of every
interview and really, it symbolizes
the love and affection that family
members have for each other. I'm
going to be showing you in the segment
here, the "In Presence" segment, various
things that I have placed around my own
home that are continual reminders for me
of various things I wish to be reminded
of. Now for me, because of my interest,
deep interest, I guess you'd have to say,
in depth psychology and parapsychology
and higher consciousness and altered
states of consciousness, the triggers are
constant reminders to me. I live in an
environment where I'm just surrounded by
these reminders. So, it's easier for me to
remember who I am.
It's easier for me to remember the
potency of consciousness.
I'd like to encourage you to look
around your environment. What can you do
to create triggers to help you un-stress,
unwind, breathe, get in touch with your
Prana, with your life energy, with your
natural healing energy? Get in touch with
your capacity for intuition and psi
awareness,
just by tiny little triggers around your
house. Works of art are really great for
that purpose. Now in my house I have many
images that are meaningful to me
personally. I have many Buddhas that I
have brought back from Thailand.
I have images from the Egyptian Book of
the Dead.
I have anthroposophical watercolor
paintings of the astral plane. I have
Chinese images of the afterlife and
Chinese images of the Arhats, the
enlightened bodhisattvas. I have
sculptures of the god Brahma. I have
symbols of the Jewish religion. These are
all meaningful to me, but of course for
you it might be quite different. I think
some people actually like images of
chaos because that's meaningful to them
right now. Perhaps working through
the chaos is very important, at one time
it was for me. And of course if you've
been watching these videos, you'll know
I've posted a lot of those images. The
point is certainly not that you should
ever think about imitating the kind of
images that you see that Jeffrey Mishlove
has, Huichol yarn paintings, for
example. I have a fondness for
psychedelic kinds of imagery. But, the
important thing is that these are
meaningful for you, that they represent
images that you find helpful because of
the particular path that you are on
right now. I encourage you to do what
you can to surround yourself with images,
visual images that represent for you
important steps that you need to take,
that represent for you
triggers that are going to put you into
what you regard as a better state of
mind. The interesting thing is it just
takes a small shift in consciousness to
go from a state where you're stressed
out, upset, not really centered and
balanced, to a state where you're more
awake, more curious, more open to what
life has to offer you.
It's a simple, subtle, little shift that
you can make. One of the best ways to
do it, I’ve mentioned earlier, is simply take
a deep breath. A simple little thing like
a deep breath can make an enormous
difference in your mind, in your
consciousness, in your attitude to life.
I’ll leave you with that thought.
Thank you once again for being with me.
